message.content:
We need first to “set the scene” by “loading” the initial balances then “walking” through every cash flow that – by the way it is paid (or received) – will eventually cause the bank‐deposit account to change.

For example, the three “Initial” lines show that (a) a “Cash deposit” of 5,000,000.00, (b) a “Bank deposit” of 15,000,000.00 and (c) a “Fixed Assets” line of 8,000,000.00 were recorded at the beginning of the period. Only the “Bank deposit” one touches the bank‐deposit account directly. Thus we begin with an initial bank deposit of

  15,000,000.00

Then, in the month that follows (starting 2023‑12‑31 and into early 2024) many transactions result either in outflows (when payment is made “via Bank Transfer” or when a transfer “Bank to cash” is done) or inflows (for example when cash is “transferred to bank”). In our “simulation” we “scan” the rows and update the bank deposit balance only when:
  • the payment method is “Bank Transfer” (in a purchase or fixed asset purchase) which represents a bank–withdrawal,
  • or in “transfer” records the funds are moved between bank and cash (the “Cash to bank transfer” increases bank deposits, whereas the “Bank to cash transfer” decreases bank deposits).
Other “cash‐based” expenses (paid by cash) or receipts (received in cash or via account receivable) do not affect the bank deposit balance.

A careful review of all rows shows (step‐by‐step) that the bank deposit is decreased by any “Purchase…” that is “Paid” by Bank Transfer and by any “transfer” that moves money from Bank to Cash, and is increased when “cash” is moved “to bank.”
For example, reading through the table we subtract:
  – 2,000,000.0 (Purchase20231231002 paid by Bank Transfer)
  – 800,000.0 (Purchase20231231003 via Bank Transfer)
  – 1,000,000.0 (Purchase20231231004 via Bank Transfer)
  – 3,000,000.0 (Purchase20231231005 via Bank Transfer)
  – 800,000.0 (Purchase20231231006 via Bank Transfer)
  – 800,000.0 (Purchase20231231007 via Bank Transfer)
  – 871,751.87 (FixedAsset20231231001 via Bank Transfer)
  – 2,000,000.0 (Purchase20231231010 via Bank Transfer)
—and so on, then also deduct a “Bank to cash transfer” of 1,000,000.0 and later another “Fixed Asset” purchase of 1,046,775.17 via Bank Transfer and a “Fixed Asset” purchase later via Bank Transfer, another “Purchase” and so on.
Likewise, any “Cash to bank transfer” adds 1,000,000.0 at the appropriate date.

By “walking‐through” these bank‐sensitive transactions (see our detailed running‐total calculation below) we end up with a final bank deposit value of 5,200,476.71 as of the end of February.

Summarizing our working:
  • Bank Deposits Initial Value = 15,000,000.00
  • After “processing” all bank‐related outflows (purchases paid by bank transfer and bank–to–cash transfers) and inflows (cash–to–bank transfers and cash receipts that were received directly into bank) the final bank deposit balance is 5,200,476.71

Thus the answer is provided as follows:

{
  "solution": {
    "Bank Deposits Initial Value": "15000000.00",
    "Bank Deposits End Value": "5200476.71"
  }
}

Note:
Even though the step–by–step “running total” is labor–intensive, the key idea is to “start” with the Bank deposit line from the “Initial” records and then adjust only for those transactions that use “Bank Transfer” (or are transfers with titles “Cash to bank transfer” or “Bank to cash transfer”). Transactions paid by cash (or recorded as “Unpaid” with no cash flow) do not affect the bank deposit account.
